qas.question: In which branch of Buddhism is it believed that there can be no divine salvation or forgiveness for karma?
In Mahayana Buddhism, what are some Mahayana sutras that are believed to remove negative karma just by the hearing of the texts?

answers.text: the Lotus Sutra, the Aṅgulimālīya Sūtra and the Mahāyāna Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra

context: In <a0_0><a4_0>Theravada Buddhism<a4_0/><a0_0/> there can be no divine salvation or forgiveness for one's karma, since it is a purely impersonal process that is a part of the makeup of the universe.[citation needed] In <a6_0>Mahayana<a6_0/> Buddhism, the texts of certain Mahayana sutras (such as <a1_0>the Lotus Sutra, the Aṅgulimālīya Sūtra and the Mahāyāna Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra<a1_0/>) claim that the recitation or merely the hearing of their texts can expunge great swathes of <a7_0>negative<a7_0/> karma. Some forms of Buddhism (for example, <a2_0>Vajrayana<a2_0/>) regard the recitation of mantras as a means for cutting off of previous negative karma. The Japanese Pure Land teacher <a8_0>Genshin<a8_0/> taught that <a3_0><a5_0><a9_0>Amitābha<a9_0/><a5_0/><a3_0/> has the power to destroy the karma that would otherwise bind one in saṃsāra.
